concern: I am absolutely disgusted at how abusive my graduate professors have been, at least in comparison to my undergraduate professors. This seems to be way more common for graduate professors. It’s just so upsetting and hard to deal with.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm here to listen and help you explore whatever's on your mind, so please feel free to share your thoughts or concerns with me.
Hey, thanks for being here. I’m just really struggling with how harsh and unkind some of my grad professors have been, and it’s been weighing on me a lot.
That sounds really tough, and it makes sense that it would weigh on you. How have you been handling this situation so far?

I’ve mostly just been trying to push through it, you know, keeping my head down and focusing on my work. It’s exhausting though, and I’m not sure how much longer I can keep it up without breaking down.

That must feel incredibly isolating, having to face this situation alone while trying to manage your workload. Can you tell me more about what it's like to feel that exhaustion and pressure, and what happens when you feel like you're on the verge of breaking down?

Yeah, it’s like this constant heaviness, just feeling drained all the time from trying to meet expectations that seem impossible. When I get close to breaking down, I just feel overwhelmed, like I can’t think straight and I start doubting if I even belong here.

It sounds like you're carrying a heavy burden of self-doubt and pressure, and it's completely understandable to feel overwhelmed when faced with seemingly impossible expectations. Can you tell me more about what happens when you start doubting yourself and your place in the program?

Honestly, when I start doubting myself, it’s like a spiral—I keep thinking I’m not cut out for this and that maybe I made a huge mistake coming here. It just eats at me, and I end up feeling stuck, like I can’t move forward or even talk to anyone about it without seeming weak.

It sounds like you're caught in a cycle of self-doubt and pressure that's making it difficult for you to feel confident in your abilities and your place in the program. It's completely understandable to feel that way when you're facing impossible expectations and trying to keep up with an exhausting workload. You've been trying to push through it on your own, but it's clear that it's taking a toll on you. What do you think would need to happen for you to feel more confident in yourself and your abilities, and less like you're struggling to keep up?

I guess I’d need to feel like I’m actually getting somewhere, like my efforts are being recognized instead of just constantly criticized. Maybe having someone in my corner, like a mentor or even just a friend who gets it, would help me not feel so alone in this mess.

It sounds like having that support system and feeling recognized for your efforts could be a game-changer for you. What would that recognition look like for you, and how could having someone in your corner help you break free from this cycle of self-doubt?

I think recognition would just be someone acknowledging that I’m trying, maybe a professor saying something positive about my work instead of always pointing out flaws. Having someone in my corner would probably help me feel less isolated, like I could vent or get advice without feeling judged, and that might stop me from spiraling so much.

It's clear that you've been craving that sense of support and validation, and it's understandable how the absence of it could make you feel like you're struggling in silence. What do you think it would be like to have someone recognize your efforts and offer support, and how could that shift your perspective on your place in the program?

I think having someone actually see my hard work and say something encouraging would make me feel like I belong here, like I’m not just failing all the time. It’d probably help me stop second-guessing myself so much and maybe even give me a little boost to keep pushing through the tough stuff.

It's great to hear that you can envision how support and recognition could positively impact your confidence and perseverance. How might you go about seeking out that support and recognition, and what steps could you take to start breaking free from this cycle of self-doubt and criticism?

I guess I could try reaching out to a professor I trust a bit more, maybe ask for feedback in a way that invites something positive, or even just talk to them about how I’m feeling. Also, connecting with other grad students who might be in the same boat could help me build that support network, you know, just to feel less alone in this.

Based on what you said, possible options include setting up a meeting with your professor to ask for feedback or simply sharing your feelings with them. Connecting with other grad students could also involve joining a study group or attending program events to build those relationships. What do you think might be the most effective first step for you?

I think starting with connecting with other grad students might be the easiest first step for me, since it feels less intimidating than approaching a professor right away. I could maybe look for a study group or just chat with some peers after class to see if we’re on the same page about stuff.

It sounds like reaching out to peers could be a great starting point for you, as it feels more approachable. What specific actions could you take to start building these connections, and how might you approach these interactions to foster a supportive environment?

I think I could start by just striking up a convo with a couple of classmates after a lecture, maybe ask if they wanna grab a coffee or study together sometime. Like, keeping it casual and just seeing if we vibe or if they’re feeling the same pressures, you know, to kinda build that mutual understanding.

That sounds like a solid plan for building connections with your peers. How might you follow up on these casual conversations, and what steps could you take to ensure that these relationships evolve into a supportive network over time?

I guess I could follow up by checking in with them again, like texting or chatting after class to see how they’re doing or if they wanna meet up again. Maybe over time, we can start sharing more about our experiences and struggles to really build that trust and support, you know?

It's great to hear that you've come up with a plan to start connecting with your peers. Building a supportive network can be incredibly helpful in navigating the challenges of grad school. Remember to approach these interactions with an open mind and a willingness to share your own experiences and struggles. This can help foster a sense of trust and understanding among your peers.
In terms of following up on these casual conversations, it's important to be consistent and show genuine interest in getting to know your classmates. You could start by suggesting a regular study session or coffee meetup, and gradually build from there.
Don't forget to be patient with yourself as you work to build these connections. It may take some time to establish a strong support network, but with persistence and a positive attitude, you can create a more fulfilling and less isolating experience in grad school.

Thanks for the advice—I really appreciate the reminder to stay open and patient as I work on this. So, um, do you think it’s okay to just focus on one or two people at first, or should I try to reach out to a bigger group right away?

Starting with a few individuals can be a great approach, as it allows you to build deeper connections and establish a strong foundation for your support network. Once you've established relationships with these initial contacts, you can gradually expand your circle by introducing them to other classmates or joining larger group settings. Remember, the key is to focus on quality over quantity, as meaningful relationships take time to develop.
Cool, that makes sense—starting small feels a lot less overwhelming. So, I’ll just focus on a couple of people for now and see how things go from there.
